DataElement.preferredName: Gastric Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Pathologic Regional Lymph Node N Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of the regional lymph node involvement for the gastric cancer based on evidence obtained from pathologic examination through completion of definitive surgery.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Relating to the stomach._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology._One criteria of the TNM staging system. N refers to the extent of lymph node involvement.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Relating to the stomach.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pathologic; caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.:One criteria of the TMN staging system. N refers to the extent of lymph node involvement.

Concepts.definition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. N refers to the extent of lymph node involvement.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 12/3/18 tmt transferred context from NCIP. Created for CRF standard harmonization. Released per final community approval. mc 5/7/12

ValueDomain.preferredName: Gastric Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer Edition 7 N Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A finding about one or more characteristics of gastric cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system.  Tumors arising at the esophagogastric junction, or arising in the stomach in a distance equal or less than 5 cm from the esophagogastric junction and crossing the esophagogastric junction are staged using the TNM system for esophageal adenocarcinoma.  Lymphomas, sarcomas, and carcinoid tumors (low-grade neuroendocrine tumors) are not included in this classification. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)_A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._One criteria of the TNM staging system. N refers to the extent of lymph node involvement._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Gastric Cancer pN3 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Gastric Cancer pN3 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Gastric cancer with metastasis in seven or more regional lymph nodes. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Gastric Cancer pN3 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Gastric cancer with metastasis in seven or more regional lymph nodes. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Gastric Cancer pN3b TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Gastric Cancer pN3b TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Gastric cancer with metastasis in sixteen or more regional lymph nodes. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Gastric Cancer pN3b TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Gastric cancer with metastasis in sixteen or more regional lymph nodes. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Gastric Cancer pN3a TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Gastric Cancer pN3a TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Gastric cancer with metastasis in 7-15 regional lymph nodes. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Gastric Cancer pN3a TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Gastric cancer with metastasis in 7-15 regional lymph nodes. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Gastric Cancer pN1 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Gastric Cancer pN1 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Gastric cancer with metastasis in 1-2 regional lymph nodes. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Gastric Cancer pN1 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Gastric cancer with metastasis in 1-2 regional lymph nodes. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Gastric cancer in which the regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

Concepts.longName: Gastric Cancer pNX TNM Finding v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Gastric cancer in which the regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Gastric Cancer pN0 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Gastric Cancer pN0 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Gastric cancer without regional lymph node metastasis.  Note: A designation of pN0 should be used if all examined lymph nodes are negative, regardless of the total number removed and examined. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Gastric Cancer pN0 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Gastric cancer without regional lymph node metastasis.  Note: A designation of pN0 should be used if all examined lymph nodes are negative, regardless of the total number removed and examined. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Gastric Cancer pN2 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Gastric Cancer pN2 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Gastric cancer with metastasis in 3-6 regional lymph nodes. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Gastric Cancer pN2 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Gastric cancer with metastasis in 3-6 regional lymph nodes. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Gastric Cancer TNM Finding v7 American Joint Committee on Cancer N Stage Stage
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A finding about one or more characteristics of gastric cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system.  Tumors arising at the esophagogastric junction, or arising in the stomach in a distance equal or less than 5 cm from the esophagogastric junction and crossing the esophagogastric junction are staged using the TNM system for esophageal adenocarcinoma.  Lymphomas, sarcomas, and carcinoid tumors (low-grade neuroendocrine tumors) are not included in this classification. (from AJCC 7th Ed.):A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.:One criteria of the TNM staging system. N refers to the extent of lymph node involvement.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: A finding about one or more characteristics of gastric cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system.  Tumors arising at the esophagogastric junction, or arising in the stomach in a distance equal or less than 5 cm from the esophagogastric junction and crossing the esophagogastric junction are staged using the TNM system for esophageal adenocarcinoma.  Lymphomas, sarcomas, and carcinoid tumors (low-grade neuroendocrine tumors) are not included in this classification. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)
A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. N refers to the extent of lymph node involvement.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
